review.title: Structured Knowledge Representation for Image Retrieval
review.abstract: We propose a structured approach to the problem of retrieval of images by content and present a description logic that has been devised for the semantic indexing and retrieval of images containing complex objects. As other approaches do, we start from low-level features extracted with image analysis to detect and characterize regions in an image. However, in contrast with feature-based approaches, we provide a syntax to describe segmented regions as basic objects and complex objects as compositions of basic ones. Then we introduce a companion extensional semantics for defining reasoning services, such as retrieval, classification, and subsumption. These services can be used for both exact and approximate matching, using similarity measures. Using our logical approach as a formal specification, we implemented a complete client-server image retrieval system, which allows a user to pose both queries by sketch and queries by example. A set of experiments has been carried out on a testbed of images to assess the retrieval capabilities of the system in comparison with expert users ranking. Results are presented adopting a well-established measure of quality borrowed from textual information retrieval.

metadata.title: Structured Knowledge Representation for Image Retrieval

sections.text: We propose a structured approach to the problem of retrieving images by content and present a description logic designed for semantic indexing and retrieval of images with complex objects. However, as with other approaches, we base low features extracted by image analysis to identify and characterize regions in an image. However, unlike feature-based approaches, we offer a syntax to describe segmented regions as basic objects and complex objects as compositions of basic objects. Subsequently, we introduce accompanying advanced semantics to define argumentation services, such as retrieval, classification, and subsumption. These services can be used for both exact and approximate mapping, using similarity measurements. Using our logical approach as a formal specification, we implemented a complete client server retrieval system that allows the user to perform both queries on the basis of a set of evaluations based on a set of queries and a set of evaluations.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we focus on content-based image retrieval, which expresses the characteristics of the image itself, i.e., its image characteristics. Most research in this area so far has focused on developing appropriate techniques for extracting relevant terms using image analysis algorithms. Current systems lead to effective, so-called low-level properties, such as color distribution or texture. Systems such as IBM QBIC1 are easily retrieved, including stamps that contain the image of a brown horse in a green field when prompted to retrieve images with brown central area.

sections.heading: 1.1 Contributions of the Paper
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to survive themselves are able to survive themselves by surviving themselves by surviving themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are not able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are not able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are not able to survive themselves, most of them are not able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are able to survive themselves, most of them are not able to survive themselves.

sections.heading: 1.2 Outline of the Paper
sections.text: In Section 3, we will describe our formal language, first its syntax, then its semantics, and begin by demonstrating some basic properties. In the following section, we will analyze the thought problems and the semantic relationships between them, and develop algorithms that can solve them. Then, in Section 5, we will illustrate the architecture of our system and propose some examples that show different aspects of our approach. In Section 6, we will present a series of experiments to assess the recoverability of the system. In the last section, we will draw conclusions and suggest guidelines for future work.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: Content-Based Image Retrieval (CBIR) has recently become a widely studied area of research. Several systems and approaches have been proposed; here we briefly report on some significant examples and categorize them in three main directions.

sections.heading: 2.1 Feature-based Approaches
sections.text: Most of the research on CBIR focuses on low-level features such as color, texture, and shape that cannot be extracted with image processing algorithms and are used to characterize an image in a feature space for subsequent indexing and similarity retrieval, thus replacing the problem of retrieving images with homogeneous content with the problem of retrieving images that are visually close to a target (Hirata & Kato, 1992; Niblak et al., 1993; Picard & Kabir, 1993; Jacobs, Finkelstein, & Salesin, 1995; Flickner et al., 1995; Bach, Fuller, Gupta, Hampapur, Horowitz, Humphrey, Jain, & Shu, 1996; Celentano & Di Sciascio, 1998; Cox, Miller, & Papathomas, 2000; Gevers & Smeulders, 2000).

sections.heading: 2.2 Approaches Based on Spatial Constraints
sections.text: This approach to the problem of image recovery focuses on finding the similarity of images in relation to spatial relations between objects within them. Normally, the focus is only on relative positions of objects that are considered as "symbolic images" or symbols, identified with a single point in 2D space. Information about the content and visual appearance of images are usually neglected.Chang, Shi, and Yan (1983) present the modeling of this type of images in relation to 2D strings, each of the strings that take into account the position of icons along one of the two planar dimensions. In this approach, retrieval of images retrieval of images retrieval of matching to simpler strings. Gudivada and Raghavan (1995) consider the objects in a symbolic image that is associated with texts in a weighted diagram. Edges - i.e. lines that represent the centrifugal of an object, are the relationships between the objects and spatial objects.

sections.heading: 2.3 Logic-based and Structured Approaches
sections.text: The idea is to associate parts of an object (and of a scene in general) with regions where an image can be fragmented into different parts. The hierarchical organization of knowledge that can be used in the recognition of an object was first proposed by Marr (1982). Reiter and Mackworth (1989) proposed a formalism of reason to characterize the characters as outlined diagrams. In their approach, the possible relative positions of the lines are fixed and highly qualitative (touch, intersect).Structured descriptions of three-dimensional images are already available in languages such as VRML (Hartman & Wernecke, 1996) or hierarchical object modeling. However, the semantics of such languages are operative, and no effort is made to automatically classify objects in relation to the structure of their manifestations. Meghini, Sebastiani, Sebastiani, and 2001, a hierarchical object is modeled.

sections.heading: 3. Syntax and Semantics
sections.text: In this section, we present the formalism that deals with the definition of composite form descriptions, their semantics, and some of the characteristics that distinguish our approach from previous ones. We note that our formalism deals with image characteristics such as shape, color, texture, but is independent of the way in which features are extracted from actual images. For the interested reader, the algorithms that we have used to calculate image characteristics in the implementation of formalism are presented in the appendix.

sections.heading: 3.1 Syntax
sections.text: We also take into account the other characteristics that typically determine the visual appearance of an image, namely color and texture.Basic shapes are referred to by the letter B and have an edge contour e (B) that characterizes them. We assume that e (B) is described as a single, closed 2D curve in a room whose origin is at the center of B. Examples of basic shapes can be circle, rectangle, with the contours e (circle).We assume that e (rectangle) =, but also any complete, rough contour of the shape of a ship - is a basic form. To make our language compositional, we consider only the external contour of a region. For example, if one region is contained in another, as in the contour outer region, the contour contour of the outer contour is explicit.

sections.heading: 4. Reasoning and Retrieval
sections.text: We see several reasons why services that can be performed in a logic for image retrieval: 1. Form Recognition: Faced with an image I and a form description D, decide whether D is recognized in I.2. Image Retrieval: Faced with a database of images and a form description D, retrieve all images in which D can be recognized. 3. Image Classification: Faced with an image I and a collection of descriptions D1,..., Dn, find the descriptions in I. In practice, I will classify by finding the most specific descriptions (with respect to subsumption) satisfied that the classification is a type of "preprocessing" recognition. 4. Description of subsumption (and classification): Faced with a (new) description D and a collection of descriptions D1,., Dn, decide whether D subsummed (or subsummed by) each Di, for i = 1.

sections.text: We would like to thank our former students G. Gallo, M. Benedetti and L. Allegretti for their useful comments and implementations, Marco Aiello for the comments on an earlier draft, Dino Guaragnella for the discussions on Fourier transformations and an anonymous arbitrator for constructive criticism that helped us improve the paper. This research was supported by the European Union, POP Regione Puglia sottomisura 7.4.1 ("SFIDA 3"), by the Italian Ministry of Education, University and Research (MIUR, ex-MURST) for the CLUSTER22 projects "Monitoraggio ambiente e territorio," work package: "Sistema informativo per il collocamento dei prodotti ortofrutticoli pugliesi" and by the Italian National Research Council (CNR) for the projects LAICO, DeMAnD and "Metodi Ragionamento Automatico nella modellazied di dominio."

sections.heading: Appendix A.
sections.text: In this appendix, we will briefly review the methods we used to extract image attributes. We will also describe the smoothing function Φ = i = complex function and the way we calculate similarity for the image attributes introduced in Section 4.2.A.1. In order to deal with objects in an image, better segmentation is required to obtain a division of the image. Multiple segmentation algorithms have been suggested in the literature. Our approach does not depend on the respective segmentation algorithm we have chosen. It is already obvious that the better segmentation, the better our system will work. In our system, we use a simple algorithm, edge recognition and regional growing.Illustration of this technique goes beyond the scope of this paper; we will limit ourselves here to describing image attributes that require successful segmentation.

referenceMentions.context: We approach the problem of image retrieval from a knowledge representation perspective, and in particular, we refer to a framework already successfully applied by Woods and Schmolze (1992) to conceptual modeling and semantic data models in databases (Calvanese, Lenzerini, & Nardi, 1998).

In this way the problem of retrieving images with homogeneous content is substituted with the problem of retrieving images visually close to a target one (Hirata & Kato, 1992; Niblak et al., 1993; Picard & Kabir, 1993; Jacobs, Finkelstein, & Salesin, 1995; Flickner et al., 1995; Bach, Fuller, Gupta, Hampapur, Horowitz, Humphrey, Jain, & Shu, 1996; Celentano & Di Sciascio, 1998; Cox, Miller, Minka, & Papathomas, 2000; Gevers & Smeulders, 2000).

In this way the problem of retrieving images with homogeneous content is substituted with the problem of retrieving images visually close to a target one (Hirata & Kato, 1992; Niblak et al., 1993; Picard & Kabir, 1993; Jacobs, Finkelstein, & Salesin, 1995; Flickner et al., 1995; Bach, Fuller, Gupta, Hampapur, Horowitz, Humphrey, Jain, & Shu, 1996; Celentano & Di Sciascio, 1998; Cox, Miller, Minka, & Papathomas, 2000; Gevers & Smeulders, 2000).

Among the various projects, particularly interesting is the QBIC system (Niblak et al., 1993; Flickner et al., 1995), often cited as the ancestor of all other CBIR systems, which allows queries to be performed on shape, texture, color, by example and by sketch using as target media both images and shots within videos.

Among the various projects, particularly interesting is the QBIC system (Niblak et al., 1993; Flickner et al., 1995), often cited as the ancestor of all other CBIR systems, which allows queries to be performed on shape, texture, color, by example and by sketch using as target media both images and shots within videos.
Examples of systems using relevance feedback include MARS (Rui, Huang, & Mehrotra, 1997), DrawSearch (Di Sciascio & Mongiello, 1999) and PicHunter (Cox et al., 2000).

More recent papers on the topic include those by Gudivada (1998) and by El-Kwae and Kabuka (1999), which basically propose extensions of the strings approach for efficient retrieval of subsets of icons.

Reiter and Mackworth (1989) proposed a formalism to reason about maps as sketched diagrams.

With reference to previous work on Vision in Artificial Intelligence, the use of structural descriptions of objects for the recognition of their images can be dated back to Minsky’s frames, and some work by Brooks (1981). The idea is to associate parts of an object (and generally of a scene) to the regions an image can be segmented into. The hierarchical organization of knowledge to be used in the recognition of an object was first proposed by Marr (1982). Reiter and Mackworth (1989) proposed a formalism to reason about maps as sketched diagrams.

With reference to previous work on Vision in Artificial Intelligence, the use of structural descriptions of objects for the recognition of their images can be dated back to Minsky’s frames, and some work by Brooks (1981). The idea is to associate parts of an object (and generally of a scene) to the regions an image can be segmented into. The hierarchical organization of knowledge to be used in the recognition of an object was first proposed by Marr (1982). Reiter and Mackworth (1989) proposed a formalism to reason about maps as sketched diagrams. In their approach, the possible relative positions of lines are fixed and highly qualitative (touching, intersecting). Structured descriptions of three-dimensional images are already present in languages for virtual reality like VRML (Hartman & Wernecke, 1996) or hierarchical object modeling. However, the semantics of such languages is operational, and no effort is made to automatically classify objects with respect to the structure of their appearance. Meghini, Sebastiani, and Straccia (2001) proposed a formalism integrating Description Logics and image and text retrieval, while Haarslev, Lutz, and Möeller (1998) integrate Description Logics with spatial reasoning.

The idea is to associate parts of an object (and generally of a scene) to the regions an image can be segmented into. The hierarchical organization of knowledge to be used in the recognition of an object was first proposed by Marr (1982). Reiter and Mackworth (1989) proposed a formalism to reason about maps as sketched diagrams. In their approach, the possible relative positions of lines are fixed and highly qualitative (touching, intersecting). Structured descriptions of three-dimensional images are already present in languages for virtual reality like VRML (Hartman & Wernecke, 1996) or hierarchical object modeling. However, the semantics of such languages is operational, and no effort is made to automatically classify objects with respect to the structure of their appearance. Meghini, Sebastiani, and Straccia (2001) proposed a formalism integrating Description Logics and image and text retrieval, while Haarslev, Lutz, and Möeller (1998) integrate Description Logics with spatial reasoning. Further extensions of the approach are described by Moeller, Neumann, and Wessel (1999). Both proposals build on the clean integration of Description Logics and concrete domains of Baader and Hanschke (1991).

Both proposals build on the clean integration of Description Logics and concrete domains of Baader and Hanschke (1991). However, neither of the formalisms can be used to build complex shapes by nesting more simple shapes.

Both proposals build on the clean integration of Description Logics and concrete domains of Baader and Hanschke (1991). However, neither of the formalisms can be used to build complex shapes by nesting more simple shapes. Moreover, the proposal by Haarslev et al. (1998) is based on the logic of spatial relations named RCC8, which is enough for specifying meaningful relations in a map, but it is too qualitative to specify the relative sizes and positions of regions in a complex shape.

Both proposals build on the clean integration of Description Logics and concrete domains of Baader and Hanschke (1991). However, neither of the formalisms can be used to build complex shapes by nesting more simple shapes. Moreover, the proposal by Haarslev et al. (1998) is based on the logic of spatial relations named RCC8, which is enough for specifying meaningful relations in a map, but it is too qualitative to specify the relative sizes and positions of regions in a complex shape. Also for Hacid and Rigotti (1999) description logics and concrete domains are at the basis of a logical framework for image databases aimed at reasoning on query containment.

Both proposals build on the clean integration of Description Logics and concrete domains of Baader and Hanschke (1991). However, neither of the formalisms can be used to build complex shapes by nesting more simple shapes. Moreover, the proposal by Haarslev et al. (1998) is based on the logic of spatial relations named RCC8, which is enough for specifying meaningful relations in a map, but it is too qualitative to specify the relative sizes and positions of regions in a complex shape. Also for Hacid and Rigotti (1999) description logics and concrete domains are at the basis of a logical framework for image databases aimed at reasoning on query containment. Unfortunately, the proposed formalism cannot consider geometric transformations neither determine specific arrangements of shapes. More similar to our approach is the proposal by Ardizzone, Chella, and Gaglio (1997), where parts of a complex shape are described with a description logic.

Both proposals build on the clean integration of Description Logics and concrete domains of Baader and Hanschke (1991). However, neither of the formalisms can be used to build complex shapes by nesting more simple shapes. Moreover, the proposal by Haarslev et al. (1998) is based on the logic of spatial relations named RCC8, which is enough for specifying meaningful relations in a map, but it is too qualitative to specify the relative sizes and positions of regions in a complex shape. Also for Hacid and Rigotti (1999) description logics and concrete domains are at the basis of a logical framework for image databases aimed at reasoning on query containment. Unfortunately, the proposed formalism cannot consider geometric transformations neither determine specific arrangements of shapes. More similar to our approach is the proposal by Ardizzone, Chella, and Gaglio (1997), where parts of a complex shape are described with a description logic. However, the composition of shapes does not consider their positions, hence reasoning cannot take positions into account. Relative position of parts of a complex shape can be expressed in a constraint relational calculus in the work by Bertino and Catania (1998). However, reasoning about queries (containment and emptiness) is not considered in this approach.
Aiello (2001) proposes a multi-modal logic, which provides a formalism for expressing topological properties and for defining a distance measure among patterns.

Aiello (2001) proposes a multi-modal logic, which provides a formalism for expressing topological properties and for defining a distance measure among patterns. Spatial relation between parts of medical tomographic images are considered by Tagare, Vos, Jaffe, and Duncan (1995). There, medical images are formed by the intersection of the image plane and an object.

Aiello (2001) proposes a multi-modal logic, which provides a formalism for expressing topological properties and for defining a distance measure among patterns. Spatial relation between parts of medical tomographic images are considered by Tagare, Vos, Jaffe, and Duncan (1995). There, medical images are formed by the intersection of the image plane and an object. As the image plane changes, different parts of the object are considered. Besides, a metric for arrangements is formulated by expressing arrangements in terms of the Voronoi diagram of the parts. The approach is limited to medical image databases and does not provide geometrical constraints. Compositions of parts of an image are considered in the work by Sanfeliu and Fu (1983) for character recognition.

In the field of computation theories of recognition, we mention two approaches that have some resemblance to our own: Biederman’s structural decomposition and geometric constraints proposed by Ullman, both described by Edelmann (1999). Unfortunately, neither of them appears suitable for realistic image retrieval: the structural decomposition approach does not consider geometric constraints between shapes, while the approach based on geometric constraints does not consider the possibility of defining structural decomposition of shapes, hence reasoning on them.

In the field of computation theories of recognition, we mention two approaches that have some resemblance to our own: Biederman’s structural decomposition and geometric constraints proposed by Ullman, both described by Edelmann (1999). Unfortunately, neither of them appears suitable for realistic image retrieval: the structural decomposition approach does not consider geometric constraints between shapes, while the approach based on geometric constraints does not consider the possibility of defining structural decomposition of shapes, hence reasoning on them. Starting with the reasonable assumption that the recognition of an object in a scene can be eased by previous knowledge on the context, in the work by Pirri and Finzi (1999), the recognition task, or the interpretation of an image, takes advantage of the information a cognitive agent has about the environment, and by the representation of these data in a high-level formalism.
However, observe that usually a Domain Closure Assumption (Reiter, 1980) is made for image databases: there are no regions but the ones which can be seen in the images themselves.

While query containment is important in standard databases (Ullman, 1988), it becomes even more important in an image retrieval setting, since the recognition of specific features in an image can be computationally demanding.

Cardoze and Schulman (1998) solve the nearly-exact point matching with efficient randomized methods, but without scaling.

Cardoze and Schulman (1998) solve the nearly-exact point matching with efficient randomized methods, but without scaling. They also observe that best match is a more difficult problem than nearly-exact match. Also Chew, Goodrich, Huttenlocher, Kedem, Kleinberg, and Kravets (1997) propose a method for best match of shapes, but they analyze only rigid motions without scaling.

The example also points out that the system is able to correctly deal with the presence of more than one instance of an object in images, which is not possible in the approaches by Gudivada and Raghavan (1995) and Gudivada (1998). On the negative side it has to be noticed that the system did not recognize the presence of a third aircraft (indeed a strange one, the B2-Spirit) in the second image of Figure 13-b), which was not segmented at all and considered part of the background.

To ease the possibility of a comparison, we adopted the approach first proposed by Gudivada and Raghavan (1995). The experimental framework is hence largely based on the one proposed there, which relies on a comparison of the system performances versus the judgement of human experts.
Furthermore, our algorithm is able to correctly deal with the presence of more than one instance of an object in images, which is not possible in other approaches (Gudivada, 1998).

metadata.abstractText: We propose a structured approach to the problem of retrieval of images by content and present a description logic that has been devised for the semantic indexing and retrieval of images containing complex objects. As other approaches do, we start from low-level features extracted with image analysis to detect and characterize regions in an image. However, in contrast with feature-based approaches, we provide a syntax to describe segmented regions as basic objects and complex objects as compositions of basic ones. Then we introduce a companion extensional semantics for defining reasoning services, such as retrieval, classification, and subsumption. These services can be used for both exact and approximate matching, using similarity measures. Using our logical approach as a formal specification, we implemented a complete clientserver image retrieval system, which allows a user to pose both queries by sketch and queries by example. A set of experiments has been carried out on a testbed of images to assess the retrieval capabilities of the system in comparison with expert users ranking. Results are presented adopting a well-established measure of quality borrowed from textual information retrieval.
